com.biorecorder.edflib.base

Class EdfWriter

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.biorecorder.edflib.base.EdfWriter
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    EdfFileWriter, EdfFilter

    public abstract class EdfWriter
extends java.lang.Object
    This abstract class is the superclass of all classes representing an output stream of data packages (DataRecords). An output stream accepts samples belonging to DataRecord and sends (writes) them to some sink.

    To write data samples to the stream we must set a EdfConfig object with the configuration information. Only after that data samples could be written correctly.

    We may write digital or physical samples. Every physical (floating point) sample will be converted to the corresponding digital (int) one using physical maximum, physical minimum, digital maximum and digital minimum of the signal.

      • EdfWriter

        public EdfWriter()

    • Method Detail

      • setConfig

        public void setConfig(EdfConfig recordingInfo)
        Sets the EdfConfig object describing the structure of the data records (data packages) that will be written. This function MUST be called before writing any data.
        Parameters:
        recordingInfo - - EdfConfig object describing DataRecords structure

      • writeDigitalRecord

        public void writeDigitalRecord(int[] digitalDataRecord)
        Writes the entire DataRecord (data pack) containing "raw" digital data from all signals starting with n_0 samples of signal 0, n_1 samples of signal 1, n_2 samples of signal 2, etc.

        Number of samples (length) for every signal: n_i = (sample frequency of the signal_i) * (duration of DataRecord).

        This method do exactly the same as the call writeDigitalSamples(digitalDataRecord, 0, dataRecordLength).

        Parameters:
        digitalDataRecord -

      • writeDigitalSamples

        public final void writeDigitalSamples(int[] digitalSamples)
        Write "raw" digital (integer) samples from the given array to the stream/file. This method do exactly the same as the call writeDigitalSamples(digitalSamples, 0, digitalSamples.length).
        Parameters:
        digitalSamples - digital samples belonging to some signal or entire DataRecord

      • writeDigitalSamples

        public abstract void writeDigitalSamples(int[] digitalSamples,
                                         int offset,
                                         int length)
        Writes «length» digital (integer) samples from the specified array starting at offset «offset» to this EDF/BDF stream/file.

        Call this method for every signal (channel) of the stream/file. The order is important! When there are 4 signals, the order of calling this method must be:
        samples belonging to signal 0, samples belonging to signal 1, samples belonging to signal 2, samples belonging to signal 3,
        samples belonging to signal 0, samples belonging to signal 1, samples belonging to signal 2, samples belonging to signal 3,
        ... etc.

        Number of samples (length) for every signal: n_i = (sample frequency of the signal_i) * (duration of DataRecord).

        The entire DataRecord (data pack) containing digital data from all signals also can be placed in one array and written at once.

        Parameters:
        digitalSamples - data array with digital samples
        offset - the start offset in the data.
        length - the number of bytes to write.

      • writePhysicalSamples

        public void writePhysicalSamples(double[] physicalSamples)
                          throws java.lang.IllegalStateException
        Write physical samples (uV, mA, Ohm) from the given array to the stream/file.

        Call this method for every signal (channel) of the stream/file. The order is important! When there are 4 signals, the order of calling this method must be:
        samples belonging to signal 0, samples belonging to signal 1, samples belonging to signal 2, samples belonging to signal 3,
        samples belonging to signal 0, samples belonging to signal 1, samples belonging to signal 2, samples belonging to signal 3,
        ... etc.

        Number of samples (length) for every signal: n_i = (sample frequency of the signal_i) * (duration of DataRecord).

        The entire DataRecord (data pack) containing digital data from all signals also can be placed in one array and written at once.

        The physical samples will be converted to digital samples using the values of physical maximum, physical minimum, digital maximum and digital minimum of of the signal.

        Parameters:
        physicalSamples - physical samples belonging to some signal or entire DataRecord
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if EdfConfig was not set

      • getNumberOfReceivedDataRecords

        public int getNumberOfReceivedDataRecords()
        Gets the number of received data records (data packages).
        Returns:
        number of received data records

      • close

        public abstract void close()
        Closes this Edf/Bdf writer and releases any system resources associated with it. This writer may no longer be used for writing DataRecords. This method MUST be called after finishing writing DataRecords. Failing to do so will cause unnessesary memory usage and corrupted and incomplete data writing.
